journal-meta.journal-title: The American Journal of Sports Medicine

author-notes.corresp: *Maurice Balke, Department of Trauma and Orthopedic Surgery, University of Witten-Herdecke, Cologne-Merheim Medical Center, Ostmerheimer Str 200, 51109 Cologne, Germany (e-mail: maurice.balke@gmail.com).

permissions.copyright-statement: © 2012 American Orthopaedic Society for Sports Medicine
permissions.copyright-holder: American Orthopaedic Society for Sports Medicine

abstract.p: Background: Calcifying tendinitis is a common and painful disorder of the shoulder characterized by the presence of calcific deposits in the tendons of the rotator cuff. When nonoperative treatment over a prolonged period of time fails, surgical treatment should be considered. Midterm success rates are inconsistent, and the role of subacromial decompression is still unclear.

Hypothesis: Our hypotheses were that the rate of supraspinatus tears after arthroscopic treatment of calcifying tendinitis is comparable with that in the contralateral uninvolved shoulder and that subacromial decompression does not have beneficial effects compared with calcium removal alone.
Study Design: Case series; Level of evidence, 4.

Methods: In 70 shoulders of 62 patients with a mean age of 54 years, arthroscopic removal of calcium deposits of the supraspinatus tendon was performed. In 44 shoulders, additional subacromial decompression was performed. After a mean follow-up of 6 years (range, 2-13 years), patients were clinically investigated, and function was statistically evaluated using Constant and American Shoulder and Elbow Surgeons (ASES) scores. Affected and contralateral shoulders were examined by ultrasound in 48 shoulders, and rotator cuff tears were documented.

Results: The mean Constant scores of the operated shoulders were significantly lower than those of the healthy shoulders (P < .001). The ASES scores significantly (P < .001) increased after surgery but were still lower than the ASES scores of the healthy shoulders (P < .001). Concerning the additional subacromial decompression, there were no significant differences in the overall ASES and Constant scores; the subitem “pain” was significantly better in the subacromial decompression group (P = .048). Ultrasound examination at last follow-up (48 shoulders) showed a partial supraspinatus tendon tear in 11 operated and 3 contralateral shoulders.

Conclusion: Although the good clinical results after arthroscopic treatment of calcifying tendinitis of the shoulder persist midterm, the affected shoulders present significantly lower clinical scores than healthy shoulders. The rate of partial supraspinatus tendon tears seems to be higher after calcium removal. Additional subacromial decompression seems to reduce postoperative pain.

body.p: Calcifying tendinitis is a common and painful disorder of the shoulder. It is characterized by the presence of calcific deposits in the tendons of the rotator cuff, mostly affecting the supraspinatus tendon. In 1941, Bosworth3 reported an incidence of 2.7% of asymptomatic calcifications among office workers. Its peak incidence occurs in individuals between 30 to 60 years of age, with a slightly higher incidence in women than men.3,4,11,25

Treatment is usually nonoperative and includes rest, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, analgesics, physiotherapy, subacromial infiltrations with corticosteroids and anesthetics, needle aspiration of the calcium deposits,4,6,15 or ultrasound-guided percutaneous calcium removal.10,28 Some authors advocate extracorporeal shock wave therapy especially when deposits are inhomogeneous.13,20,21,30 In some cases, calcifications will resorb during the natural progression of disease. When nonoperative treatment over a prolonged period of time fails, surgical treatment should be considered. Surgical removal of the calcifications offers reliable pain relief,1,18 but pain may decrease slowly over the first postoperative year.27 While arthroscopic procedures become more and more common, removal of the calcific deposits can still be done as an open surgery. Most authors recommend removal of the calcific deposits optionally combined with subacromial decompression in case of subacromial irritations.§ However, the arthroscopic technique is demanding, as localization of the calcium deposits is often hindered by a hypertrophic bursa.18 In most cases, overlying tendon fibers have to be incised to open the deposit.

The purpose of this study was to investigate the midterm outcome after arthroscopic treatment of calcifying tendinitis of the shoulder. Outcomes were measured using the American Shoulder and Elbow Surgeons (ASES) and Constant scores. The development of rotator cuff tears was documented by ultrasound, and the effect of additional subacromial decompression was statistically evaluated.

sec.title: Materials and Methods
sec.p: Seventy consecutive shoulders of 62 patients with calcifying tendinitis were treated arthroscopically from 2000 to 2007 (Table 1). During this period, 9 additional patients received surgery for this diagnosis but did not have adequate follow-up. Calcifications were preoperatively verified by standard radiographs and by ultrasound examination of the affected and the contralateral shoulder. The calcium deposits were classified radiologically according to Mole et al.14 Radiographs of 53 of 70 shoulders were available. The mean age of the patients at surgery was 54 years (range, 39-78 years); 27 were women, and 43 were men. Shoulders were symptomatic for a mean of 2.6 years (range, 0.5-15 years). Before surgery was considered, nonoperative treatment consisting of subacromial injections and physiotherapy was conducted for at least 6 months without improvement of symptoms.

All patients were operated on in the beach-chair position under general anesthesia. First, diagnostic arthroscopy was performed in a standardized manner. The arthroscope was inserted through a posterior portal, and the glenohumeral joint was evaluated first. Associated intra-articular findings were documented. Then, the arthroscope was moved to the subacromial space, and a lateral portal was established. After bursal debridement, the calcium deposit was located using percutaneous needling and the preoperative radiographs. The overlying tendon was carefully longitudinally incised in line with the tendon fibers using a No. 11 scalpel, and the deposit was removed using a full radius resector and curettes. Additional subacromial decompression was performed if fraying of the coracoacromial ligament or erosions of the undersurface of the acromion were observed. These patients had a type II or III shape according to Bigliani et al2 on the preoperative radiographs (44 shoulders).

A standardized rehabilitation protocol was used without immobilization and immediate range of motion exercises as tolerated. After a mean follow-up of 6 years (range, 2-13 years), patients were clinically evaluated, and function was compared using the postoperative Constant and the preoperative and postoperative ASES scores. The affected as well as the contralateral shoulders were examined by ultrasound in 48 shoulders, and tears of the rotator cuff were documented. All ultrasounds were performed by the same fellowship-trained orthopaedic surgeon with 10 years of ultrasound experience. The criteria for partial tears were fluid within the tendon resulting in hypoechoic or hyperechoic areas or thinning of the tendon of more than 50%. Thirty-eight of the patients also had a symptomatic contralateral shoulder; thus, only 24 asymptomatic shoulders were available for comparisons. In 8 patients, both shoulders were operated because of calcifications.

Statistical analyses were performed using Microsoft Excel 2007 (Redmond, Washington) and SPSS 13.0 (Chicago, Illinois). Preoperative and postoperative scores as well as scores for the operated and healthy shoulders were compared using the t test for independent samples. The influence of additional subacromial decompression was calculated using the Mann-Whitney test.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: All calcium deposits were located in the insertion of the supraspinatus tendon. The classification of the deposits according to Mole et al14 is summarized in Figure 1. Preoperative ultrasound examinations did not detect any partial- or full-thickness rotator cuff tears. The mean Constant score of the operated shoulder of 76.2 points was significantly lower than that of the healthy shoulder with 88.8 points (P < .001) (Table 2). The preoperative ASES score of 39.4 points significantly (P < .001) increased to 82.7 points after surgery but was still lower than the ASES score of the healthy shoulders with 92.2 points (P < .001) (Table 3). Regarding the additional subacromial decompression performed in 44 shoulders, there were no significant differences in the overall ASES and Constant scores. However, the subitem “pain” of the Constant score was significantly better in the subacromial decompression group (11.4 compared with 12.9 points; P = .048) (Table 2). Subacromial decompression did not have any significant influence (P = .859) on the incidence of partial rotator cuff tears.

caption.p: Radiological classification of calcium deposits. The radiological appearance of the calcium deposits was classified according to Mole et al.14 Preoperative radiographs were available for review for 53 shoulders. (A) Homogeneous, well-defined limits. (B) Heterogeneous, fragmented, well-defined limits. (C) Heterogeneous, poorly defined limits. (D) Dystrophic pattern.

fn.label: a
fn.p: ADL, activities of daily living; ASD, arthroscopic subacromial decompression.

fn.label: b
fn.p: All contralateral versus healthy contralateral versus postoperative shoulders. Only 24 patients had a healthy contralateral side. The mean Constant score of the operated shoulders of 76.2 points was significantly lower than that of the healthy shoulders with 88.8 points (P < .001).

fn.label: c
fn.p: ASD (n = 44) versus no ASD (n = 26). There were no significant differences in the overall scores, but subitem “pain” scored significantly better in the ASD group (11.4 compared to 12.9 points; P = .048).

caption.p: American Shoulder and Elbow Surgeons (ASES) Scoresa

fn.label: a
fn.p: ASES scores of preoperative, postoperative, all contralateral, and healthy contralateral shoulders (n = 24). Preoperative ASES score of 39.4 points significantly (P < .001) increased to 82.7 points after surgery but was still lower than the ASES score of the healthy shoulders with 92.2 points (P < .001).

sec.p: Ultrasound examination at last follow-up (48 available shoulders) showed a partial supraspinatus tendon tear in 11 of the operated shoulders compared with 3 of the contralateral shoulders. There were no significant differences in the clinical scores when comparing partial tears with intact tendons (Constant score: 68.6 vs 77.0 points, respectively, P = .083; ASES score: 77.0 vs 81.9 points, respectively, P = .091).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Although open excision of the calcifications in refractory calcifying tendinitis of the rotator cuff is an effective procedure,12,22 it is nowadays generally performed arthroscopically.‖ Most authors find that the postoperative time period until pain relief is generally more than 6 months, which can be affirmed by our results.1,16,24,27 Patients should be educated on this topic when considering surgery. The excellent results reported by Seil et al,27 with an average Constant score of 91 points after arthroscopic treatment, were not achieved in our patients. Although the beneficial effect was clearly evident after surgery, the function of the operated shoulders was significantly worse than that of the healthy shoulders, even after more than 2 years. The reason for this finding remains speculative. One might assume that the rate of rotator cuff lesions of the operated shoulders is higher than that of the contralateral side. In our study, there was a tendency toward an increase in partial cuff lesions after calcium resection diagnosed by ultrasound but without statistical significance. Whether these tears developed over time or reflected residual scar tissue because of the surgical incision of the tendon remains speculative. There were no significant differences in the clinical scores when comparing partial tears and intact tendons. This is in agreement with the findings of Seil et al,27 who published that ultrasonographic changes were still visible in 60% of patients at 2 years, without being of clinical relevance. They concluded that the small incision of the tendon, which was also performed in our patients, did not lead to major structural changes of the tendons.27 Porcellini et al,16 on the other hand, did not observe any cuff tears by ultrasound at 2 years and advocated suturing of the tendon after resection of a bigger deposit. Seil et al postulated that it does not seem to be necessary,27 which complies with our approach. Taking into account that we only observed partial cuff lesions without clinical relevance, arthroscopic removal seems to be a safe procedure regarding damage of the rotator cuff.

The role of subacromial decompression in addition to resection of the calcium deposits is also a matter of debate. Some authors state that it does not positively influence the results and thus is not necessary in most cases.1,9,16 Ark et al1 and Porcellini et al16 recommend acromioplasty only if there are signs of subacromial impingement. In the latter study, this was the case in only 6 of 63 shoulders and did not affect clinical outcome.16 Seil et al27 reported similar findings. They performed additional subacromial decompression if there were signs of mechanical subacromial irritation or if there were residual calcifications and did not find any differences in the Constant scores.27

Several publications have reported a beneficial effect of acromioplasty without calcium removal for the treatment of calcifying tendinitis. Schiepers et al26 successfully treated 13 shoulders by acromioplasty, of which less than half also received excision of the calcifications. This did not influence the final results. They found that the calcifications had disappeared in all cases and stated that the treatment of the associated impingement might be more important than the removal of the calcifications.26 Tillander and Norlin29 reported that the calcifications had disappeared in 54% of their cases after isolated subacromial decompression. Postel et al17 published a comparable rate of 70%. The authors assumed that treatment of the subacromial impingement caused resorption of the calcifications.

Gleyze et al7 compared 30 patients treated by arthroscopic calcium resection with 30 patients who additionally received an acromioplasty but did not find any difference. Similar results are published for an open procedure by Hofstee et al.8 They compared 2 groups of patients with calcifying tendinitis that were treated by open acromioplasty with and without removal of the calcifications.8 After a 3-year follow-up, there were no significant differences in the Disabilities of the Arm, Shoulder and Hand (DASH) score, range of motion, pain, and patient satisfaction between the 2 groups. The authors stated that the additional removal of the calcium deposits does not further improve the results compared with acromioplasty alone. All published studies so far have not found any beneficial effect of additional acromioplasty. Although in our study the overall clinical scores also did not differ with or without decompression, the subitem “pain” of the Constant score was significantly better in the subacromial decompression group. This finding might be incidental. Because patients were not randomized for additional acromioplasty, there might be a selection bias. But because there were no adverse events related to the decompression and postoperative pain is the most serious complaint of the patients, an additional acromioplasty might be considered for selective patients.

This study was limited by its retrospective design. It was also not randomized for additionally performed subacromial decompression. Because of the lack of postoperative radiographs, we cannot correlate our results with the amount of residual calcifications.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Although the good clinical results after arthroscopic treatment of calcifying tendinitis of the shoulder persist in the midterm, the affected shoulders have significantly lower clinical scores than healthy shoulders. The rate of partial supraspinatus tendon tears seems to be higher after calcium removal. Additional subacromial decompression seems to reduce postoperative pain.

fn.p: The authors declared that they have no conflicts of interest in the authorship and publication of this contribution.
